results.title: Charles Dickens: background for his works
results.brief_description: Scenes photographed in England, showing many of the actual places which Dickens used as settings in his novels and also town and country houses where he wrote some of his best-known novels. Views of historic inns and buildings in London, Rochester, Canterbury, Dover and the marshlands of “Great Expectations”. A page from the MS of “Pickwick Papers”; another from the MS of “Oliver Twist”. The film stresses the relation between Dickens’ stories and his personal experience of places, people and social customs.

results.title: Charles Chauvel: the action director
results.brief_description: Compilation film containing interviews with Elsa Chauvel, Sir Norman Rydge, Chips Rafferty, Betty Bryant, Marsden Hessall, and others who worked with Charles Chauvel. Long excerpts from his seven sound features, including “40,000 Horsemen” and “Jedda”. Includes B&W sequences.

results.title: Charlemagne: holy barbarian
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas, International Film Associates and Learning Corporation of America
results.brief_description: The story of Charlemagne’s campaign against the Saxons. Focuses on one campaign waged by Charlemagne against the Saxons in 782, in order to examine whether brutality in the name of civilisation is justified. Discusses the cultural contribution of Charlemagne, and shows the ruthless means he employed to accomplish his goals.

results.title: Charlemagne and his empire
results.brief_description: Pictures Charlemagne’s conquests , his close ties with the Roman Church, his system of government, and his many contributions to life in the Middle Ages. Shows how Charlemagne hoped to keep civilization and culture alive on the European continent during the early years of the Middle Ages. No other credits available.

results.title: Chardin and the female image (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Paul Kafno, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Examines the paintings of Chardin in relation to the tradition of portraying the female image, and compares his work to that of contemporaries such as Fragonard, Watteau, Boucher and Greuze

results.title: Character make-up: youth & age
results.brief_description: This program deals with character make-up, youth and age. Laura Bradish demonstrates the application of character make-up as a young actress is transformed into an old woman.

results.title: Character - Setting - Plot
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Writers on Writing”.
Writers on Writing is based on a growing archive of video material of contemporary writers discussing their work. The material has been re-edited to form a resource for students and teachers of English, and each of the six twenty-minute videos focuses on different aspects of the writing process. Each video is accompanied by a resource booklet. This video examines how characters are created, and how important are setting and plot.

results.title: Chapter and verse
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, Paul Rotha, National Book Council and Strand Films
results.brief_description: The history of printing is traced from its beginning to modern methods of large scale production in English Publishing Houses and the distribution and marketing of the finished book. At the same time, the film follows the life of an individual book, beginning with the author’s MS, the reading of the proofs, the printing, binding, sale to shops and final use in libraries where it is indexed and catalogued.

results.title: Chaplin's first films
results.brief_description: A selection of Chaplin’s early films illustrating the development of his art form from slapstick to a subtle mixture of pathos and comedy. Excerpts from the following are included in this compilation: “Some Nerve”, “Making a Living”, “Mabel’s Strange Predicament”, “Tillie’s Punctured Romance”, “His Prehistoric Past”, “The Champion” and “The Tramp”.
